Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Conference on Music Perception and Cognition (ICMPC) is an interdisciplinary conference devoted to the dissemination of new, unpublished research relating to the neuroscientific, psychological, and computational bases of music perception and cognition. Founded in 1989, ICMPC is an international collective made up of research societies from different parts of the world, including the Society for Music Perception and Cognition in North America, the European Society for the Cognitive Sciences of Music, and the Asia-Pacific Society for the Cognitive Sciences of Music.

This award will provide support for a number of graduate students to attend the International Conference on Music Perception and Cognition (ICMPC), to be held July 5-9, 2016 at the University of California San Francisco (UCSF). Awardees will be enrolled in a Ph.D. program at a U.S. institution and will present their work at the ICMPC. Awardees will be selected to enrich the diversity of the conference in terms of geographical, cultural, and ethnic backgrounds and gender balance. ICMPC will host a lunch for all award recipients to meet and network with the keynote speakers and other award recipients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of the Program in Perception, Action, and Cognition at the National Science Foundation, the International Conference on Music Perception and Cognition (ICMPC) was a great success. ICMPC was held in San Francisco July 5-9, 2016, and attracted 550 attendees from 31 different countries resulting in 249 dynamic talks and 263 poster presentations. The conference proceedings may be found online at:

http://www.icmpc.org/icmpc14/files/ICMPC14_Proceedings.pdf

Notably, many authors chose to submit short papers in lieu of an abstract-only contribution to the proceedings, making this document extremely useful for those who did not attend the conference and would like details of the cutting edge research that was presented.

The financial support provided by the Program in Perception, Action, and Cognition enabled four U.S. graduate student travel grants to be awarded to extraordinary research projects. Applicants provided a 2,000 word short paper describing their research and were judged by a panel of four senior experts in the field. The top four U.S. graduate students were each awarded funds to cover travel expenses (up to $2000). In addition, awardees were provided a 30-minute slot for their spoken presentation, when most attendees only received 15 minutes. Furthermore, awardees were acknowledged at the conference, on the website, in the program and in the conference proceedings. More importantly, they were able to meet with senior researchers in their field and expand their scientific network internationally, which will undoubtedly help develop their scientific careers.
